Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Overview and Introduction

(2) Abstract

This introductory lecture gives the motivation for the course, some information about the people involved and the organization of the course, a high-level overview of the course's topics, and an overview of the assignments which are an important part of the course program.



Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Overview and Introduction

(3) Course Goals

  • Understanding how the Web works
  • Publishing information on the Web
  • Providing services on the Web
  • Managing information on the Web
    • lectures focus on principles and technologies
    • assignments focus on applications
    • tools are important but secondary
  • An Overview of the Web as an Open Information System


Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Overview and Introduction

(4) What this Course Is Not

  • Not a skills course
    • You will get some hands-on experience, but you won't learn to be a web developer
  • Not a visual design course
    • Design in the sense of architectural pattern, not design in the sense of visual layout
  • Not an interaction design course
    • But knowing architectural principles is a prerequisite for good interaction design on the Web


Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Overview and Introduction

(5) Web Architecture and Information Management

Architecture
6. Computing. The conceptual structure and overall logical organization of a computer or computer-based system from the point of view of its use or design; a particular realization of this. (OED)
Management
1. a. Organization, supervision, or direction; the application of skill or care in the manipulation, use, treatment, or control (of a thing or person), or in the conduct of something. (OED)
  • Learning the conceptual structure and organization of the Web
  • Understanding how the Web is being applied to the manipulation, use, treatment, and control of information
  • Thinking about and knowledgeably discussing how the Web is and can be used


Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Overview and Introduction

(6) Web Architecture and Information Management

  1. Part 1: Building Blocks of the Web
    • History and background of the Web
    • Filesystems and directory structure
    • Foundations of Web page design (HTML & CSS)
    • Web browsers
    • Communications (Internet & HTTP)
    • Web applications and databases
    • Client-side scripting (JavaScript & Ajax)
    • Multimedia content (pictures & audio/video)
  2. Part 2: Web-based Information Management
    • Web search engines and other intermediaries
    • Syndication (RSS & Atom)
    • Semantic Web (Microformats & RDFa)
    • Mobile Web
    • Real-time Web (Twitter et al.)
    • Web values: Security & privacy
    • Web values: Openness & transparency

(8) About this Course

  • Course Web page: https://elearning.uh.edu/ [https://elearning.uh.edu/]
  • Greg's email address: greg@uh.edu [greg@uh.edu]
  • Letter grade based on group & individual maintenance assignments, participation, attendance, mid-term exam, and paper
    • maintenance assignments: no grade, but can take away up to 60% of your grade if you do not complete them.
    • participation: 20%
    • attendance: 20%
    • mid-term exam: 30%
    • paper: 30%

(10) Assignments

  • Group Work
  1. There will be two (2) group assignments at the beginning of the semester.
  2. Work in groups of four (4).
  3. Those who do the work in the group, simply MAINTAIN a grade status quo. Those who do not contribute to the group project (and it is reported to me) will lose ten percent (10%) of their overall grade.
  4. No one's role is more important than the other. To make this apparent to the group, prove it.
  5. Everyone is talented. Working with people that are opposite you will surpirse you. The most talented share what they know with others to help everyone move UP AND TO THE RIGHT (i.e. grow and move forward). Life is too short to bog yourself down with competing with someone else. At the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation there is an African proverb that is refered to often which says: “If you want to go fast, go alone. If you want to go far, go together."

  • Suggestions for a successful group project experience would be:
  1. Leader - Choose someone who will lead. No leader is perfect, but a good leader can help everything run smoothly.
  2. Recorder - Choose someone who is quick on the computer and organized. This person knows social media and they also are able comfortable using collaborative learning tools like Google Docs.
  3. Researcher - Choose someone who has computer skill, but will specifically feel comfortable using Google Scholar and the UH Online Library.
  4. Host - Choose someone who will organize when and where to meet. This person will assist the leader break down tasks and get things accomplished. Who knows, this person may have a sweet house to meet at and provide food for everyone...


Organizational Issues Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Overview and Introduction

(11) Course Reading

  • Van Dijk, J. (2012). The network society. Sage Publications.
  • Read the book on your own time (Thursday nights or whenever).
  • For personal use if you want to listen to the book as audio, I will show you how to do this outside of class.
  • There will be an exam based on the book readings.
  • We will have a review for the mid-term.
  • The mid-term will be ten (10) essay questions over the main topic of each chapter. If the book is not read carefully, the concepts will not be understood by the reader, therefore the essay will be weak. Weak essays produce low grades.


Organizational Issues Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Overview and Introduction

(12) About these Slides

  • Generated from Hotspot [http://dret.net/projects/xslidy/] XML [web-spring10.xml]
  • Designed for online presentation and use (lots of links!)
    • Firefox Go Up [http://dret.typepad.com/dretblog/2008/07/go-up.html] allows easy navigation up one level
    • Firefox Site Navigation Bar [https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/1949] supports navigation of link links
    • Firefox Link Widgets [https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/2933] requires a bit more configuration (more flexibility)
    • for printing, use a (all slides), and then s (smaller font) a couple of times
  • A good real-world example for Web-based publishing
    • Slidy/Kilauea is useful, but there is no support for structures and hyperlinking
    • Hotspot adds these features by adding an XSLT transformation
    • Hotspot is useful, but there is no interface (XML editing only)


Organizational Issues Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Overview and Introduction

(13) Additional Resources

  • Online Glossary at http://dret.net/glossary/ [http://dret.net/glossary/]
    • suggestions, updates, corrections are welcome
    • another exercise in how to use XML and XSLT for information management
  • W3 Schools HTML Tutorial [http://www.w3schools.com/html/default.asp]
    • With HTML you can create your own Web site.
    • This tutorial teaches you everything about HTML.
    • HTML is easy to learn - You will enjoy it.
  • The World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) [http://www.w3.org/]
    • headed by Tim-Berners Lee [http://www.w3.org/People/Berners-Lee/], inventor of the Web (with Robert Cailliau [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Cailliau])
  • The Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) [http://www.ietf.org/]
    • mainly Internet standards, but also responsible for URIs and HTTP

Course Topics Gregory Jonason

(15) Course Overview

  • 50/50 mix of foundations and applications
  • Week 01: History and background of the Web
  • Weeks 02-07: Building Blocks of the Web & Group Presentations
  • October 17: Mid-term exam (10 essay questions over Chapters 01-10 [comprehensive])
  • November 28-29: Thanksgiving Break
  • Weeks 09-15: Web-based Information Management & Guest Speakers
  • Dec 12: 10 Page Paper Due (20 original sources and 10 quotes)


Course Topics Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Overview and Introduction

(16) Building Blocks of the Web

  1. Week 01
    [Introduction] & [Overview]
  2. Week 02
    [Standards and Standards Bodies] & [Filesystems and Web Servers]
  3. Week 03
    [Hypertext Markup Language (HTML)] & [Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) & Web Browsers]
  4. Week 04
    [Internet Architecture] & [Web Foundations (URIs & HTTP)]
  5. Week 05
    [Group Presentations - Lego Standards Plan]
  6. Week 06
    [Anatomy of a Basic Web Application] & [Media Types (MIME)]
  7. Week 07
    [Group Presentations - Github Open Website]

  8. Week 08
    [Mid-term Exam]


Course Topics Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Overview and Introduction

(17) Web-Based Information Management

  1. Week 09
    [Multimedia] & [State Management (Cookies)]
  2. Week 10
    [Client-side Scripting] & [Anatomy of an Advanced Web Application]
  3. Week 11
    [Web Search] & [Web Intermediaries]
  4. Week 12
    [Content Syndication (Atom & RSS)] & [Third-party Content]
  5. Week 13
    [Semantic Web, Linked Data & Microformats]
  6. Week 14
    [Guest Lecture] & [Mobile Web and Real-time Web]
  7. Week 15
    [Guest Lecture] & [Security and Privacy, Open Access and the Open Web]

  8. Week 16
    ["Reading Day" - Not Class] & [10 Page Paper (Due by 11:00 pm)]

  • Hour after hour

  • Makes us stronger
